GameEventAction.Description:
The Ikkuro serve the land and the sky. These have always guided our path.
The land: since days before memory, we have sought to live in harmony with our world, to nourish it and thrive alongside it. We are part of nature, and we seek to exist with the plants and animals that surround us, not to dominate them.
The sky: The ancient myths of our ancestors say we originated beyond the stars. As we became more sophisticated, and science filled the gaps in our knowledge, our intellectuals rejected these stories as nonsense. But as our scientific knowledge grew, we began to discover variances with our biology and that of the world around us. Then we realized that ancient relics, once central to primitive religious practices, were artifacts of an ancient Ikkuro civilization. It now seems likely that the myths of our ancestors grew from the seeds of truth, and that our point of origin is, indeed, to be found on other worlds.
Is there truth in the myths that say our ancestors were driven to this world by a terrible Cataclysm that destroyed civilizations across the galaxy? Were there truly monsters who began a terrible war that sparked the Cataclysm? Monsters are but other beings, so why were our ancestors unable to reason with them, to show them the way of peace and coexistence?
We must discover the truth. Our study of ancient relics and ruins has helped us to move closer to mastering the secrets of faster-than-light travel. We have discovered caches of resources not native to this world, but these exist only in limited supply. We must find more of these recourses if our research is to continue. Only by advancing our knowledge can we understand our origin. Only by understanding who we were and what drove us to this place can we hope to live in peace with all those we may encounter among the stars.

Though our space exploration program has only recently begun, we have already made an incredible discovery. Damazy appears to harbor intelligent life. Our growing body of evidence has suggested that there must be other intelligent life in the galaxy, but we never expected to find it so close to our own system. We must proceed cautiously and respectfully.

After monitoring the communications of this world, we have discovered that these are beings who call themselves the Children of the Conflict-Averse. They belong to a species called the Dhayut, and their legends also speak of an origin from beyond the stars. Interestingly, their legends speak of ancestors saved from the ancient Cataclysm by a species that resemble our kind. Once, these stories say, the Children of the Conflict-Averse were warlike and cruel, but the Ikkuro-like saviors not only rescued them from destruction but also showed them a better, more harmonious way. The Ikkuro-like beings of their stories are the subjects of almost divine reverence in their culture.
We have also discovered that this world has a bountiful supply of Giraxian Nectar.
Though, like us, the Children of the Conflict-Averse have only just begun to explore the universe beyond their world, our scans indicate they possess large stockpiles of resources vital to space exploration and travel. It is also worth noting that, despite their name, the Children of the Conflict-Averse have an advanced military.
We must be careful in how we proceed with these beings. It is the Ikkuro way to strive for harmonious existence with all, but we live in a universe with finite resources. If we could convince the Children of the Conflict-Averse to share their bounty with us, it would greatly enhance our expansion, but can we risk taking advantage of them?
GameEventAction.ChoiceButtonText: Begin a cautious program of cultural exchange - 15,000cr
Take advantage of their myths to expedite diplomacy.

GameEventAction.Description:
Treading carefully, we have contacted key political figures among the Children of the Conflict-Averse and introduced ourselves and our culture. The people of their world have shown nothing but delight at being contacted by beings so revered in their ancient stories. Indeed, these Children of the Conflict-Averse strive to live in accordance with the finest Ikkuro principles. They have explained to us that their ancestors were very different. They were warlike and cruel and deceptive, even attempting to make common cause with the invaders who caused the Cataclysm. They credit aliens, whom they believe to be our ancestors, with saving them from both physical and spiritual destruction.
The Ikkuro of our homeworld are delighted by these developments, and the presence of friendly, intelligent life in this system seems to have inspired our scientists to work with a new vigor. The Children of the Conflict-Averse are eager to continue contact with us, and it seems as though their enthusiasm for fellowship will only increase as time goes on.
We Appreciate Your Diplomatic Efforts
We Really Appreciate Your Diplomatic Efforts

We have contacted the Children of the Conflict-Averse to make our presence known. Though we cannot prove that we are the same beings they credit with saving their ancestors, it has done them no harm to let them believe it is so. After all, they strive to live in harmony with nature, and they can learn much from observing us.
Their initial impulse has been to shower us with gifts. We can see no reason not to let them indulge their reverence. To do otherwise would be to ask them to act in variance with their nature.
They have launched 4 ancient Ikkuro escorts into orbit and have placed them under our control.
Also they have sent 3,000 caslon to our homeworld.

It may have been a mistake to allow the Children of the Conflict-Averse to shower us with gifts. They did so of their own will and without our prompting, but there appears to be some growing resentment of us on their world. We ought to have anticipated this. It is always disappointing to meet one's idols.
Disappointment in meeting our idols

"It was only a matter of time before we encountered you. Our advance scouts warned us of your existence, though, to be honest, many believed you could not be real. We are the Harmonious Void, those who seek to seek peace and understanding in the quiet vacuum of space. Our ancestors were once attached to soil and unprocessed air as you are, but we have moved beyond such limitations.
Your primitive insistence upon world-dwelling does not disturb us, however. We respect life, be it advanced like us or primitive like you, provided it is in harmony with its surroundings. Our concern is the existence of fiends who called themselves the Children of the Conflict-Averse. We recognize them as Dhayut, who are, by their nature, deceptive, selfish, and destructive. In the time before the Cataclysm, they fought alongside the evil invaders, destroying entire worlds, including that of our ancestors. The Dhayut are enemies of life. If you tolerate their existence near your home system, we will not tolerate your presence near OUR home system. There is no other choice we believed to be harmonious."

"We offer you not greetings, Dhayut, but a warning. We are the Harmonious Void. We seek to live in a peace and harmony with all who dwell in this resource-rich system. That is why you cannot be permitted to dwell here. We know your kind to be treacherous, cruel, and enemies of peace. Your presence her cannot be tolerated. Flee while you can."
We will not tolerate your kind

"Greetings visitors to our system. We are the Harmonious Void. We seek to live in peace and harmony with all who dwell in this resource-rich system. Provided your mission is one of exploration and understanding, we will allow you passage. Any effort to establish any permanent foothold in our home system, however, will be viewed as unharmonious."
We are open to better relations

These pirates who call themselves the Harmonious Void are of our species, but they are driven by hatred. Perhaps we could convince them of the error of their ways and allow them to experience the harmony they seek in pointless aggression. We must also consider that this system from which they would bar us contains useful resources, which would aid our own quest for harmonious expansion. War is rarely the best course, but sometimes it is required for the greater unity. In our past, we have sometimes been forced to engage in what is known as a War of Mercy. This may be such a time.

GameEventAction.GeneratedItemName: Declare a War of Mercy Choice (Ikkuro)

GameEventAction.Description: Our diplomats have begun negotiations with the Harmonious Void. They were more willing to speak to us than we first feared, but they are even more stubborn than we first suspected. In the end, they have asked for a token of respect. We are to refrain from hostile actions until we have "proved ourselves their friends." Until that time, any attack on their ships will greatly harm our efforts.
You Invested in Diplomacy

GameEvent.Name: Declare a War of Mercy Choice (Ikkuro)

GameEventAction.Description: The Harmonious Void has forced us to show them the error of their ways. Only once they are defeated, can they hope to seek true enlightenment.
You Declared a War of Mercy!

We are receiving a message form the leader of the Harmonious Void.
"{15}, you have defeated us in fair combat. As we have fought a war, and we have been vanquished, we must conclude that our efforts to seek harmony have failed. We ask only mercy for our surviving civilians. It may take some adjusting for them to learn your ways, but in the end, they will become productive members of your society. Will you accept these refugees?"
"Thank you for this offer of refuge. What little we have remaining to us is given as a token of thanks."
They have paid us 20,000cr in war reparations.
2M refugees have arrived on our homeworld.
We have recieved 5,000 Caslon, 2,500 Rephidium Ale and 2,500 Caguar Fur. These have been delivered to our homeworld.

As the refugees flee away from our space, we have uncovered several stashes of resources and materials. These will be useful as we continue to grow and expand, seeking to live in peace with all we encounter.
We have recieved 10,000 Caslon, 5,000 Rephidium Ale and 5,000 Caguar Fur. These have been delivered to our homeworld.

We've made a remarkable discovery. On {0}, which long ago suffered severe seismic damage, we have discovered the entrance to an ancient Ikkuro facility. This is particularly remarkable because there is no other indications of construction by Ikkuro or any other species. What was the purpose of this building, and why did the ancients build here? Our early investigations reveal nothing, but we cannot face the future without first understanding the past. We will continue to study and learn.
Our engineers studying the ancient facility on {0} believe that the knowledge to unlock this door could be derived if we fully understand Large Fuel Storage technology.

GameEventAction.MessageTitle: To Prioritize or not to Prioritize
GameEventAction.Description: We have not yet completed this research. We must decide if we want to prioritize Large Fuel Storage to open the ancient facility or if we wish to prioritize other research.
Our scientists are making this research their top priority.
We trust our scientists to pursue what technology that think will best serve our civilization. They will inform us when we have achieved the knowledge to open the ancient facility.

Our scientists have entered the ancient Ikkuro facility. It appears to be some sort of data vault, though the databanks are largely damaged and decayed. It seems as though the facility was destroyed by the seismic damage at afflicted the rest of this world.
There are a few surviving mentions of an ancient invaders waging war upon the galaxy. There is also mention of their allies, the Dhayut Web, toward whom our ancestors bore particular animus. We cannot determine why. The answer may be related to a star chart which reveals a location that seems to be of great significance. We should investigate.
We have also discovered an ancient tome, The Book of Harmonious Necessity. This is a fascinating philosophical justification for why the preservation of life may sometimes require violent and even pre-emptive war. Any scientist reading this work would no doubt be inspired when researching weapons technology.

A remarkable discovery. On {0}, which long ago suffered severe seismic damage, we have discovered the entrance to an ancient facility likely built by the Ikkuro, which some of our legends suggest were once enemies of our kind. There is no indication of construction by any other species. What was the purpose of this building, and why did they build here? Our early investigations reveal nothing, but we should learn more to discover what past dangers and treacheries may await us as we expand further into our place in the galaxy.
Our engineers studying the ancient facility on {0} believe that the knowledge to unlock this door could be derived if we fully understand Large Fuel Storage technology.

GameEventAction.MessageTitle: To Prioritize or not to Prioritize
GameEventAction.Description: We have not yet completed this research. We must decide if we want to prioritize Large Fuel Storage to open the ancient facility or if we wish to prioritize other research.
Our scientists are making this research their top priority.
We trust our scientists to pursue what technology that think will best serve our civilization. They will inform us when we have achieved the knowledge to open the ancient facility.

Our scientists have gained entrance to the ancient Ikkuro facility. It appears to be some sort of data vault, though the databanks are largely damaged and decayed. It seems as though the facility was destroyed by the seismic damage at afflicted the rest of this world. No doubt the Ikkuro deserved to suffer.
There are a few surviving mentions of an ancient invaders waging war upon the galaxy. There is also mention of their allies, the Dhayut Web, toward whom the Ikkuro bore particular animus. We have found a star chart which reveals a location that seems to be of great significance. It may be worth our effort to investigate.
We have also discovered an ancient tome, The Book of Harmonious Necessity. This is a strange philosophical justification for why the preservation of life may sometimes require violent and even pre-emptive war. Why should war require such tortured excuses? It is an alien concept, and difficult to understand, and yet it offers unexpected insights. Any scientist reading this work would no doubt be inspired when researching weapons technology.

A remarkable discovery. On {0}, which long ago suffered severe seismic damage, we have discovered the entrance to an ancient facility likely built by the aliens known as the Ikkuro. There is no other indications of construction by Ikkuro or any other species. What was the purpose of this building? Our early investigations reveal nothing, but it may be worth our while to investigate further.
Our engineers studying the ancient facility on {0} believe that the knowledge to unlock this door could be derived if we fully understand Large Fuel Storage technology.

GameEventAction.MessageTitle: To Prioritize or not to Prioritize
GameEventAction.Description: We have not yet completed this research. We must decide if we want to prioritize Large Fuel Storage to open the ancient facility or if we wish to prioritize other research.
Our scientists are making this research their top priority.
We trust our scientists to pursue what technology that think will best serve our civilization. They will inform us when we have achieved the knowledge to open the ancient facility.

Our scientists have gained entrance to the ancient Ikkuro facility. It appears to be some sort of data vault, though the databanks are largely damaged and decayed. It seems as though the facility was destroyed by the seismic damage at afflicted the rest of this world.
There are a few surviving mentions of an ancient invaders waging war upon the galaxy. There is also mention of their allies, the Dhayut Web, toward whom the Ikkuro bore particular animus. We cannot determine why. The answer may be related to a star chart which reveals a location that seems to be of great significance.
We have also discovered an ancient tome, The Book of Harmonious Necessity. This is a philosophical justification for why the preservation of life may sometimes require violent and even pre-emptive war. Any scientist reading this work would no doubt be inspired when researching weapons technology.
This damaged world shows signs of having once been inhabited. Initial data suggests the inhabitants were Ikkuro. This warrants further exploration.

We can now confirm that this heavily damaged world was once a thriving center of Ikkuro culture. The seismic damage indicates destruction during the ancient Cataclysm, but there are troubling signs of a terrible conflict prior to those events. Mass graves and indications of orbital bombardment tell us that the ancient Ikkuro participated in a war that spanned the galaxy. We can only speculate on what sort of threat would have been significant enough for our ancestors to embrace conflict on this scale.
Almost no major facilities remain standing or even excavatable, but on a large, isolated island, we have identified two relatively intact buildings: an archive, likely containing records of the past and a warehouse, which may contain resources of immediate value. They are close to one another, and our engineers believe excavating one will make the other permanently inaccessible.

We can now confirm that this heavily damaged world was once infested with Ikkuro. The seismic damage indicates destruction during the ancient Cataclysm, but there are signs of a conflict prior to those events. Mass graves and indications of orbital bombardment tell us that the ancient Ikkuro were much hated in the ancient galaxy.
Almost no major facilities remain standing or even excavatable, but on a large, isolated island, we have identified two relatively intact buildings: an archive, likely containing records of the past and a warehouse, which may contain resources of immediate value. They are close to one another, and our engineers believe excavating one will make the other permanently inaccessible.

We can now confirm that this heavily damaged world was once inhabited by the Ikkuro. The seismic damage indicates destruction during the ancient Cataclysm, but there are signs of a conflict prior to those events. Mass graves and indications of orbital bombardment tell us of destruction prior to the Cataclysm.
Almost no major facilities remain standing or even excavatable, but on a large, isolated island, we have identified two relatively intact buildings: an archive, likely containing records of the past and a warehouse, which may contain resources of immediate value. They are close to one another, and our engineers believe excavating one will make the other permanently inaccessible.

This was the administrative building of the Peaceful Scythe, which we believe was a faction or perhaps political party that rose to prominence during a galactic conflict called the Shakturi War. The Shakturi are described as invaders, though from where we cannot guess. Among their most feared allies were the ancient Dhayut Web. It seems that the purpose of the war was not to defend territory or reclaim worlds, but to destroy the Shakturi and their allies.
There is now overwhelming evidence that this was a war waged on a galactic scale and conglomeration of Ikkuro worlds, called the Ikkuro Harmony, chose to participate fully in fighting the Shakturi and their allies.
This is a troubling revelation. Conflict is a part of nature, and it can be unavoidable, even beneficial to the greater good. Nevertheless, we cannot imagine the circumstances that led our ancestors to join in a war on this scale, to become willing participants in an effort to destroy an entire species. Data retrieved from the archive can assist us with some of our defensive research, which we may need sooner than later. The galaxy appears to be a far more dangerous and chaotic place than we previously imagined.
We have also found a reference to a terraforming research facility, whose location we have been able to identify. This is worth investigating.

This was the storehouse administered by the Peaceful Scythe, which we believe was a faction or perhaps political party that rose to prominence during a galactic conflict called the Shakturi War.
This storehouse contains a large supply of polymer and carbonite. Records suggest it came from a source in this system.

This was an administrative building established during the Shakturi War. There is much mention of the Shakturi's feared allies, the Dhayut Web.
We have also found a reference to a terraforming research facility, whose location we have been able to identify. This is worth investigating.
This storehouse was maintained during the Shakturi War. It contains a large supply of polymer and carbonite. Records suggest it came from a source in this system.

This was an administrative building established during the Shakturi War. There is much mention of the Shakturi's allies, the Dhayut Web.
We have also found a reference to a terraforming research facility, whose location we have been able to identify. This is worth investigating.
This storehouse was maintained during the Shakturi War. It contains a large supply of polymer and carbonite. Records suggest it came from a source in this system.

This is a pristine world that somehow escaped the ancient war. Our preliminary investigation indicates that the Ikkuro faction known as the Peaceful Scythe operated a terraforming facility here. The world itself appears to have served as a proof of concept for their terraforming technology. It is well protected, however. We will have to determine the best way to gain access.
Our engineers have studied scans of the defense platforms, and they believe they can fashion a small fleet of sapper drones that will damage the shields of the defense platforms. Our ships will then be able to move in and quickly destroy them. It will an expensive undertaking, however.

GameEventAction.ChoiceButtonText: Face the Platforms Without Damaging Them
GameEventAction.GeneratedItemName: Face the Platforms Without Damaging Them Choice (Ikkuro)

GameEventAction.Description: This is a world that somehow escaped the ancient war. Our preliminary investigation indicates that the Ikkuro faction known as the Peaceful Scythe operated a terraforming facility here. The world itself appears to have served as a proof of concept for their terraforming technology. It is well protected, however.

This is a world that somehow escaped the ancient war. Our preliminary investigation indicates that the Ikkuro faction known as the Peaceful Scythe operated a terraforming facility here. The world itself appears to have served as a proof of concept for their terraforming technology. It is well protected, however.
Our engineers report that their sapper drones were successfully deployed. They have functioned as expected, and the defense platforms are now heavily damaged. Our ships can quickly destroy them.

GameEvent.Name: Face the Platforms Without Damaging Them Choice (Ikkuro)

GameEventAction.Description: Our ships will now have to eliminate the defense platforms without additional aid.

Much as we suspected, this world is ideal for Ikkuro habitation, no doubt because of the application of ancient terraforming technology. After a search of the few existing planetary facilities, we have discovered the Tree of Creation, a hologram monument to the wonders of remaking unhospitable words to make them more to our liking. This will give us significant advantages for any terraforming we might undertake.

This world is ideal for Ikkuro habitation, not for us. It appears to have been altered by the application of ancient Ikkuro terraforming technology. After a search of the few existing planetary facilities, we have discovered the Tree of Creation, a hologram monument to planetary reshaping. This will give us significant advantages should we attempt to make an inhospitable world more suited to our needs.

This world appears to have been altered by the application of ancient Ikkuro terraforming technology. After a search of the few existing planetary facilities, we have discovered the Tree of Creation, a hologram monument to planetary reshaping. This will give us significant advantages should we attempt to make an inhospitable world more suited to our needs.

An anti-Ikkuro revolution has broken out on Damazy. Early reports indicate that all Ikkuro are being rounded up and executed. A faction calling itself the Web of Destiny is claiming to now be in control.

We are receiving a transmission from the Web of Destiny on Damazy.
"Ikkuro of {15}, take note. We are the Web of Destiny. We know the legends of your benevolence are false. We know your ancestors attempted to impose their twisted values upon us, and you do the same. We will no longer tolerate Ikkuro oppression. We are your enemies now and always."
You are our eternal enemies
An anti-Ikkuro faction has gained power on Damazy. A group calling calling itself the Web of Destiny is claiming to now be in control.

We are receiving a transmission from the Web of Destiny on Damazy.
"Ikkuro of {15}, take note. We are the Web of Destiny. We know the legends of your benevolence are false. We know your ancestors attempted to impose their values upon us, and you do the same. We will no longer tolerate an Ikkuro presence near our system. We are your enemies now and always."
You are our eternal enemies

The Dhayut of Damazy may still be antagonistic toward us, but we have taken control of their world. We have captured several of their ships still under construction, and discovered that they have managed to obtain a great deal of information about the ancient war with the Shakturi.
In particular, they have come to believe that the ancient Ikkuro embarked upon a genocidal campaign against the Dhayut. They have identified a far-off planet as the site of Ikkuro activity against the Dhayut in this long ago war.

Perhaps we were too trusting. We respected local customs and requests for privacy. As a result, the Dhayut of Damazy were able to build a base and ships without noticing. Perhaps we were nave to believe these were "projects of a religious nature."
GameEventAction.ChoiceButtonText: Attempt to reach out to loyal Dhayut (30,000cr)

GameEventAction.GeneratedItemName: Neighbour System War of Mercy Choice (Ikkuro)

GameEventAction.Description:
Our operatives have attempted to reach out to the Dhayut of Damazy who are still loyal to us and who appreciate what our ancestors did for them. There may be more of these than the Web of Destiny would like to believe. Many of the loyalists are in positions of power, and they are willing to fight for our side.
3 of their newly constructed destroyers have been stolen by these loyalists and are now under our control.

GameEvent.Name: Neighbour System War of Mercy Choice (Ikkuro)

GameEventAction.Description:
Our people are outraged by the betrayal of Damazy. We are determined to fight this faction in an attempt to return harmony to our local systems. We have already captured a supply ship carrying a large stockpile of enemy resources. We shall defeat this uprising in the end.
Opinion polls on our homeworld largely indicate support for the war, but they also indicate that our people expect us to wrap it up within a year.

The Dhayut of Damazy may still be antagonistic toward us, but we have destroyed their main planetary defense base. We have captured several of their ships still under construction, and discovered that they have managed to obtain a great deal of information about the ancient war with the Shakturi.
In particular, they have come to believe that the ancient Ikkuro embarked upon a genocidal campaign against the Dhayut. They have identified a far-off planet as the site of Ikkuro activity against the Dhayut in this long ago war.

The Dhayut of Damazy may still be antagonistic toward us, but we have captured their main planetary defense base. We have captured several of their ships still under construction, and discovered that they have managed to obtain a great deal of information about the ancient war with the Shakturi.
In particular, they have come to believe that the ancient Ikkuro embarked upon a genocidal campaign against the Dhayut. They have identified a far-off planet as the site of Ikkuro activity against the Dhayut in this long ago war.
You are our Gods

This world appears to have belonged to an ancient Ikkuro faction called as best as we can translate it, the Vulnerable Farming Implements. Preliminary scans suggest that this is an unappealing Forest world. It is protected by automated defenses. The world itself is of no value to us, but there may be interesting information about the past on the surface.
This world appears to have belonged to an ancient Ikkuro faction called the Peaceful Scythe. Preliminary scans suggest that this is a Forest world. It is protected by automated defenses.

This world appears to have belonged to the ancient Ikkuro faction called the Peaceful Scythe. Preliminary scans suggest that this is a pristine Forest world, ideal for colonization. Moreover, this world likely contains important information about the Ikkuro of the time of the ancient Catacylsm. Penetrating its automated defenses may be challenging, but it is likely well worth the effort if we are to achieve harmony with the past.
Our engineers believe they can effectively sabotage at least some of this world's automated defenses. The undertaking will be costly, but will making gaining access to the surface significantly easier.
Our military must now destroy this world's defenses if we are to discover what lies on the surface.
Our engineers have been successful. This world's defenses have been significantly reduced. It is now up to our military to finish the job.

On the surface of Kasim we have discovered a population of genetically modified Dhayut. Evidently they were altered during the ancient times by the Ikkuro faction, the Peaceful Scythe. Much like the Dhayut of Damazy, they have legends that liken the Ikkuro to gods. These Dhayut seem incapable of thinking of us in any other capacity. Their nature is so subservient that they could never revolt against any Ikkuro.
We have been able to construct what we believe to be an accurate timeline of some past events. During the war against the Shakturi, the Dhayut emerged as particularly brutal allies of the great enemy, evidently taking delight in destroying entire worlds. The Ikkuro, always preferring peace, initially wished to stay out of the conflict, but upon witnessing the scale of the destruction, our ancestors felt they had no choice but involve themselves. In particularly, the dedicated themselves to defeating the Dhayut wherever they could be found, even if that meant destroying the species entirely.
The Peaceful Scythe arose from this decision, finding the pursuit of genocide to be unacceptable. Instead, they sought to remake the Dhayut into a species that could live in harmony with a peaceful galaxy.
Though, like other Ikkuro, they recognized the threat the Dhayut presented to the galaxy, they sought to change rather than destroy the enemy. They created a bioagent that would alter the Dhayut, make them capable of thriving on worlds suitable for Ikkuro, and removing entirely the aggression and deviousness so integral to the Dhayut nature. This was a multipart treatment, administered by different components over different generations.
The ancients did not leave us the secrets of creating the bioagents, but we have found a large supply of the final treatment. It would not work on ordinary Dhayut, but our scientists believe it would work to change the genetic code of the Dhayut of Damazy. If we were to use the bioagent, those Dhayut would never again make war on us.
Now we, like our ancestors, must engage in a difficult moral decision. Do we alter the nature of another people to make them more like us or do we respect life as we have found it?

On the surface of Kasim we have discovered a population of genetically modified Dhayut. Evidently they were altered during the ancient times by the Ikkuro faction, the Peaceful Scythe. Much like the Dhayut of Damazy, they have legends that liken the Ikkuro to gods. These Dhayut seem incapable of thinking of us in any other capacity. Their nature is so subservient that they could never revolt against any Ikkuro.
We have been able to construct what we believe to be an accurate timeline of some past events. During the war against the Shakturi, the Dhayut emerged as particularly brutal allies of the great enemy, evidently taking delight in destroying entire worlds. The Ikkuro, always preferring peace, initially wished to stay out of the conflict, but upon witnessing the scale of the destruction, our ancestors felt they had no choice but involve themselves. In particularly, the dedicated themselves to defeating the Dhayut wherever they could be found, even if that meant destroying the species entirely.
The Peaceful Scythe arose from this decision, finding the pursuit of genocide to be unacceptable. Instead, they sought to remake the Dhayut into a species that could live in harmony with a peaceful galaxy.
Though, like other Ikkuro, they recognized the threat the Dhayut presented to the galaxy, they sought to change rather than destroy the enemy. They created a bioagent that would alter the Dhayut, make them capable of thriving on worlds suitable for Ikkuro, and removing entirely the aggression and deviousness so integral to the Dhayut nature. This was a multipart treatment, administered by different components over different generations.
What horrors must our ancestors have endured that they would consider rewriting another sentient species' genetic code. It is fortunate that we have no need to resort to such extremes. Perhaps we can study this bioagent and learn to apply this technology to aid our more harmonious objectives.

We have deployed the bioagent on Damazy. The results are almost immediate. The Dhayut population has become peaceful, and the leadership have reached out to us, asking for forgiveness. They have announced that they wish only to live in harmony with us, and that they welcome the presence of Ikkuro on their world.
The results are not as well received throughout {15}. Many question the ethics of transforming the nature of a population, particularly when that population presented no existential threat to any other species. Our ancestors created the technology to allow them to make the decisions of gods. Now we must live with the consequences of using that technology.
We have made one more significant discovery on the surface of Kasim: an ancient star chart. It reveals the location of the ancient Ikkuro homeworld.

It is not our place to remake another species to render them more to our liking. Though we would rather they were more agreeable, the population of Damazy must be free to choose their own destiny, even if it is a violent one. They must be true to their nature as we have remained true to ours.
We have made one more significant discovery on the surface of Kasim: an ancient star chart. It reveals the location of the ancient Ikkuro homeworld.

On the surface of Kasim we have discovered a population of genetically mutilated Dhayut. It seems the ancient Ikkuro used vile technology to change the nature of these Dhayut making them peaceful, subservient, and weak.
According to existing records, these abominations were created by an Ikkuro faction determined to remove the threat of the Dhayut. They have so twisted the local population that these Dhayut view Ikkuro as though they are gods.
By examining records and torturing some of the locals, we believe we have discovered the horrible truth of this world. During the ancient Shakturi war, the Ikkuro found the Dhayut so formidable and terrifying, they set out to destroy us. Some, in accordance with their twisted beliefs, did not like to contemplate violence and instead chose the more horrific path of attempting to remake Dhayut in their own image. Fortunately, most of the components required for this horrific metamorphosis no longer exist. We need not fear we will be transformed into abominations.
As for the twisted, useless Dhayut of this world, we must decide what do with them. There seem to be only two logical choices.

The population of Kasim has been destroyed. This is a great relief to all of Dhayut-kind. Among the ruins we have discovered what we believe to be the location of the ancient Ikkuro homeworld. Perhaps there is something of value to be found there. Perhaps not.

The population of Kasim has been enslaved. These genetically altered abominations are a useful reminder of how other species cannot be trusted. Perhaps, though they do not deserve to live, these Dhayut can take some comfort in living out their lives in miserable utility.

On the surface of Kasim we have discovered a population of peaceful Dhayut. From what we have been able to discover, ancient Ikkuro used bioagents to alter the nature of the Dhayut, transforming them from violent to peaceful. This happened during the ancient Shakturi War, when at least some of the Ikkuro believed the Dhayut were an existential threat. A fanatical splinter faction, in an effort to avoid the risk of destroying an entire species, sought to wished to remake the Dhayut in their own image.
Among the records, we have discovered the location of the ancient Ikkuro homeworld.

We have discovered our ancient homeworld. This was once a forest world teeming with harmonious life, but following the Cataclysm it has become unrecognizable and uninhabitable. It was upon this world that the Ikkuro learned to understand their place as a part of nature, not the center of it. What wonderous life once thrived here that is now gone forever? It is painful to contemplate such questions, but we can draw strength and determination from this loss. We can renew our determination to protect life elsewhere.
We have discovered the homeworld of the vile Ikkuro. This was once a world infested with forests, but the ancient Cataclysm seems to have purged it. At least some good came of that horrible event.
We have discovered what appears to be the ancient homeworld of the Ikkuro. It may be worth exploring.

On our ancient capital world, we have learned a great deal about our past. Along with fragments we have already discovered, we believe we can now piece together a timeline of our role in the ancient conflict. The Ikkuro first sought to remain neutral during the Shakturi war, believing all war to be evil, but when we witnessed the devastation wrought by the Shakturi, particularly the destruction caused by their World Destroyers, we knew we had no choice but to involve ourselves. When a core Ikkuro world, teeming with diverse life, was destroyed by Dhayut forces, our ancestors concluded that the Dhayut lived by an ethos so contrary to life that they had to be fought more ruthlessly than any war in our history. A war of benevolent destruction was declared. A splinter group within the military, calling itself the Peaceful Scythe, believed that war pursued with such viciousness would change who we were as Ikkuro, and so they resolved instead to genetically alter the Dhayut, making them more like us. They established a modified Dhayut colony near an already established Ikkuro colony. When the Cataclysm happened, both colonies were left on their own.
In the ruins of our homeworld we've uncovered astonishing relics that speak to how our ancestors were able to live in communion with the natural world. Among our discoveries are the Talisman of the Wise Navigator, which will improve our ships.
We have also discovered the Orb of Thriving, which will make our colonies more prosperous.
This world was once a thriving center of all Ikkuro research. Rebuilding research facilities here will no doubt aid our own efforts to understand the universe in which we live and of which we are only a small part. Such knowledge as we gain here should only add to our understanding, and that, in turn, will add to our humility.

On the ancient Ikkuro capital world, we have learned a great deal about their past schemes and plots. The Ikkuro were initially too cowardly to enter the Shakturi war, hiding behind their pretense that war is bad or some such nonsense, but when the might of Shakturi World Destroyers forced them to realize their cowardice would not save them, they somehow found the motivation to defend their miserable lives. Better they should have embraced destruction. The singled out the Dhayut for their pathetic attempts at war, but a twisted faction within their ranks sought to remake our kind rather than face us in battle. These warped fiends, calling themselves the Peaceful Scythe, sought to turn the Dhayut into a different sort of peace-loving Ikkuro. They established a colony of these abominations in the same system as one of their own Ikkuro colonies. Perhaps we should investigate.
In the ruins of their devastated world we've uncovered some curious artifacts. Perhaps they could be of use to us. Among these are the Talisman of the Wise Navigation, which will improve our already excellent ships.
We have also discovered the Orb of Thriving, which will make our colonies, which require no alien help, even more prosperous.
The pathetic Ikkuro dabblers engaged in what they called research here. We must grudgingly admit that the facilities look excellent, and we would be well advised to take advantage of what the Ikkuro have wrought. A research base here will serve us well.

Prior to the Cataclysm, this was likely a thriving forest world. Despite the massive damage to this world, we have discovered some important artifacts. Among our discoveries are the Talisman of the Wise Navigation, which will improve our ships.
We have also discovered the Orb of Thriving, which will make our colonies more prosperous.
This world was once a thriving center of all Ikkuro research. Rebuilding research facilities here will no doubt aid our own research efforts.
